comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/27331537@N06] Thanks for bringing that to us - a lovely tribute to the bridge and those who risked all to build it! A reminder that this state can build great infrastructure when it really wants to!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: At 00:16 - I never realized the northside tram, road, and rail were like that originally.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content:
[http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00]

This is how that area looked a couple of years before

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper/5427844554/]

and another

[http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper/5427241793/in/photostream/]

The tramway bridge in the video, was the world's longest tramway only bridge at the time. 

The bridge was originally  designed, of course, by Bradfield for the eventual railway line to Mosman and Manly-Warringah which would pass through North Sydney Station and then turn right in the tunnels under Shore School and head north.  

During the bridge construction of the North Shore rail tunnel the rail junction and northward tunnels were actually built so when the rest of the Warringah-line was built the construction would not disrupt traffic on the North Shore line. They actually had foresight, and planned ahead in those days. Let's hope the new infrastructure department or commission that Barry O'Farrell plans will plan ahead like this! We live in hope!

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Thanks for that!  I am trying to find a 1930s street map . . .

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: Back in 2004 Gregory's published a limited edition 1934 edition ... you my still be able to pick one up from The Map Shop or Universal directly. I find it very helpful when tracing old tramway tracks. There were a number of chabges in North Sydney necessitated by the northern approaches of the Sydney Harbour Bridge.

comment.author: 32162360@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/johncowper] Thanks! I meant to say an interactive and referable online 1930s street map, such as these tram maps I have bookmarked - 1893 - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-rm1281-v 1903 - nla.gov.au/nla.map-rm1635 1917 - www.nla.gov.au/apps/cdview?pi=nla.map-gmod71-v They take a bit of getting used to, the zoom function is slow, but I find they show all kinds of useful detail. You might find tramways you never knew existed.

comment.author: 21647809@N04
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/32162360@N00] Hey, they're great, lots to explore there! many, many thanks -- John
